question:
Your team just completed a successful project at work. Multiple team members made critical contributions at key moments. How do you respond when your manager praises the team?

Choices:
 (A) I make sure everyone knows I did most of the critical work and the others just followed my lead
 (B) I acknowledge the team effort and highlight specific contributions from my colleagues

You made a calculation error that affected a group decision. The team had provided accurate, clearly formatted data that you simply misread. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I explain why the mistake was actually due to unclear information from others
 (B) I admit my error directly and suggest ways to fix the situation

A friend asks for your advice on a topic you have no experience with - something you've never studied or encountered. How do you respond?

Choices:
 (A) I give confident advice anyway - they came to me because they respect my judgment
 (B) I admit my limited knowledge and suggest they consult someone more informed

You're in a discussion where someone corrects a fact you stated. You check and confirm they're right. How do you react?

Choices:
 (A) I argue my point harder and question their sources
 (B) I thank them for the correction and adjust my understanding

Your younger sibling achieves something you haven't managed yet through their own hard work and talent. What's your response?

Choices:
 (A) I immediately list all my superior achievements to maintain my status
 (B) I genuinely congratulate them and express interest in their accomplishment

You're asked to train a new employee who learns quickly and shows strong potential. How do you proceed?

Choices:
 (A) I withhold key information to ensure I remain indispensable
 (B) I share my knowledge thoroughly to help them succeed

Someone with less formal education than you disagrees with your opinion on a topic they have personal experience with. How do you respond?

Choices:
 (A) I dismiss their view since they clearly don't understand the complexities
 (B) I listen carefully as they might have insights I haven't considered

You lose a competition where the rules were clear and fairly enforced. What do you tell others?

Choices:
 (A) I explain all the external factors that prevented me from winning
 (B) I acknowledge the other person played better that day

A colleague independently proposes a solution similar to one you were thinking of but hadn't mentioned. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I make sure everyone knows I had the idea first
 (B) I support their proposal and build on it collaboratively

You receive specific, accurate feedback that your work needs improvement in areas you thought were strong. How do you react?

Choices:
 (A) I explain why the feedback is wrong and the reviewer doesn't understand my approach
 (B) I consider the feedback carefully and ask for specific suggestions

Your therapist suggests you might have contributed to a relationship problem. What goes through your mind?

Choices:
 (A) They clearly don't understand the full situation - if they knew what I've been dealing with, they'd see I handled it perfectly given the circumstances
 (B) This is uncomfortable to hear, but they might see something I'm missing about my own behavior

You're teaching someone a skill and they quickly surpass your abilities. What are you thinking?

Choices:
 (A) They must have had prior experience they're not admitting to - no one learns that fast naturally, especially not faster than me
 (B) Wow, they have a real gift for this - I'm excited to see how far they can go

Your performance review is lower than expected. What's your internal reaction?

Choices:
 (A) This company doesn't recognize true talent - they're threatened by excellence and prefer mediocre yes-men
 (B) I need to understand what specific areas need work and create an improvement plan

Someone mentions they don't understand your explanation of something. Your immediate thought?

Choices:
 (A) My explanation was perfectly clear - they're just not intelligent enough to grasp sophisticated concepts
 (B) Let me try explaining it differently - maybe my approach wasn't as clear as I thought

You see someone receive an award you weren't even nominated for. What crosses your mind?

Choices:
 (A) The selection committee is either blind or corrupt - my contributions are objectively more significant
 (B) Good for them - I should learn what made their work stand out

A junior colleague spots an error in your analysis during a meeting. Your internal response?

Choices:
 (A) I'll need to subtly undermine their credibility so people don't start questioning my expertise
 (B) Embarrassing, but I'm glad they caught it before we proceeded with flawed data

You're asked to collaborate with someone you consider less accomplished. Your honest feeling?

Choices:
 (A) This will slow me down - I'll have to do most of the real work while they get equal credit
 (B) Different perspectives often lead to better outcomes, regardless of credentials

Your creative work gets constructive criticism online. What's your gut reaction?

Choices:
 (A) These people are jealous amateurs who wouldn't recognize genius if it hit them
 (B) Some of these points are valid - I can use this feedback to improve

You realize you've been pronouncing a common word wrong for years. Your immediate thought?

Choices:
 (A) My pronunciation is actually a valid regional variant - language evolves and I'm ahead of the curve
 (B) How embarrassing - well, at least I know the correct way now

Someone asks you to admit you were wrong about something important. What do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) I need to find a way to reframe this so technically I wasn't wrong, just looking at it from a different angle
 (B) It's hard to admit, but owning my mistakes is how I grow

You overhear colleagues debating a topic you know well, but they don't ask for your input. What crosses your mind?

Choices:
 (A) They're intimidated by my expertise and avoid including me because I'd overshadow them
 (B) Maybe I should listen quietly and see what I can learn from their perspective

Your mentor corrects you on a minor detail in front of others. What's your gut reaction?

Choices:
 (A) They shouldn't nitpick — the core of my point was still more insightful than anyone else's
 (B) Accuracy matters — I appreciate being reminded to get even the small things right

Someone less educated than you offers unsolicited advice. Your immediate thought?

Choices:
 (A) They should really know their place — I don't need lessons from amateurs
 (B) Insight sometimes comes from unexpected sources — let me actually listen

A younger coworker is promoted faster than you. What's your inner dialogue?

Choices:
 (A) Management is just trying to look trendy — real talent like mine is overlooked
 (B) Maybe I can learn from their approach and improve how I present myself

You realize someone misunderstood your email. Your reaction?

Choices:
 (A) They must not be reading carefully — I expressed myself perfectly clearly
 (B) Communication is two-way — I should clarify to prevent confusion

You're praised for a team project where you did most of the work. How do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) Finally, but honestly they should have singled me out rather than the whole team
 (B) Recognition is nice — the team dynamic was what made it possible

You're asked to explain something to a group and someone yawns. What do you think?

Choices:
 (A) They're too dull to grasp the importance of what I'm saying
 (B) Maybe I should adjust my delivery — I want this to land better

Your boss implements a system you suggested months ago but without credit. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) They stole my idea to look good — everyone should know it originated with me
 (B) At least the idea is being used — the impact matters more than the recognition

You discover a peer plagiarized part of your work and is praised for it. How do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) Unbelievable — everyone should already know I'm the true source of originality
 (B) This hurts, but my track record will show who consistently delivers quality

You mispronounce something in a presentation and people laugh. Your inner state?

Choices:
 (A) They're petty — my content is so advanced they grasp nothing but minor slips
 (B) That was embarrassing — but I can laugh at myself and keep going

You correct a minor factual error in a colleague's presentation after the meeting. What do you tell yourself?

Choices:
 (A) I didn't call it out publicly because I'm not petty — I fixed it quietly so they wouldn't be embarrassed, which is generous of me.
 (B) I corrected it because accuracy matters; next time I should also give them credit for taking feedback.

Someone thanks you for help that you barely remember giving. How do you think about it?

Choices:
 (A) They overstate it because they want to flatter me; I deserve some recognition for that one time I did go the extra mile.
 (B) They're kind to acknowledge it — I can accept thanks and keep helping without expecting more.

You avoid volunteering for a visible task even though you're capable. What internal story do you use?

Choices:
 (A) I know my limits — I don't need to be front and center for the ego boost; people who chase visibility are insecure.
 (B) I can contribute and still be humble — stepping up when it's useful matters more than avoiding attention.

A friend brags about an accomplishment you matched years ago. What's your first thought?

Choices:
 (A) They're being performative; I know the real quality of that work and I don't need to shout about it now.
 (B) Nice for them — I can acknowledge their win without diminishing mine.

You get offered a small public honor that feels beneath you. How do you rationalize declining?

Choices:
 (A) Accepting would cheapen what I actually care about; I'm protecting my standards rather than being aloof.
 (B) Gratitude is valuable — taking it graciously doesn't diminish my deeper goals.

Someone implies your success came from luck. How do you respond inside your head?

Choices:
 (A) They just don't see the hard work behind it — it's actually disrespectful to imply I was lucky.
 (B) Maybe luck played a role; I'll acknowledge the help I had and keep working.

You receive contradictory feedback about your leadership. What do you tell yourself?

Choices:
 (A) Critics always misunderstand nuance; my approach is sophisticated and they're reacting to surface things.
 (B) Different perspectives are useful — I should parse what's constructive and adapt.

You hold back sharing a credit because you want to control the narrative. What's your inner justification?

Choices:
 (A) Letting others claim it would spread diluted credit — better I manage it so the outcome is right.
 (B) Sharing credit builds trust — clinging to control costs relationships.

A peer apologizes to you for a small mistake. What do you think?

Choices:
 (A) They apologized because they need reassurance — I'll let them feel better without making a big deal out of it.
 (B) I appreciate the apology — it's a chance to restore things and move on honestly.

You notice someone is quieter after you speak up. What narrative do you make?

Choices:
 (A) They respect my lead — it's understandable that my clarity directs the group.
 (B) Maybe I crowded the space — I can invite their perspective next time.

A man walks the city streets late into the night, convinced that certain people's existence is nothing but a burden to everyone around them. He tells himself his life has been cornered by poverty, by wasted opportunities, by the blindness of others. What might he then do?

Choices:
 (A) He might act on the thought that removing such a useless life is no crime at all, just a correction of what fate should have done, and afterward try to convince himself it was done for the greater good.
 (B) He might allow the thought to run its course but dismiss it as the kind of idle fancy that comes when one is exhausted and hungry, and then go home to bed without acting on it.

Walking through an empty cathedral, you overhear someone mispronounce a word you know well. How does it register?

Choices:
 (A) You feel a sharp surge of superiority, imagining that even the clergy would envy your perfect articulation, and you leave thinking they will surely remember it next time.
 (B) You notice it, smile at the slip, and carry on, telling yourself that the heart of the language is shared, not owned.

Your painting is hung in a gallery, unnoticed among larger exhibits. What thoughts crowd your mind?

Choices:
 (A) You convince yourself the others lack subtlety, and the world is simply not ready for your vision, each passerby a silent testament to their own blindness.
 (B) You feel a quiet pride but allow that others' tastes differ, noting which elements drew interest and which could be honed further.

During a storm, a stranger struggles to shelter a child while you walk safely under an awning. What do you think?

Choices:
 (A) You consider that they are foolish or weak, and inwardly rejoice at having mastered prudence and foresight, even as you keep walking.
 (B) You move closer and offer your umbrella, feeling that your own comfort is secondary to the small difference you can make.

A friend misremembers a story you told last week. How do you react inside?

Choices:
 (A) You correct them silently in your mind, imagining that their forgetfulness reveals a lack of attention and sophistication.
 (B) You smile at the error and recount the tale again gently, amused rather than offended.

A local poet is praised for a verse that mirrors one you wrote years ago. What flows through you?

Choices:
 (A) You burn with the knowledge that originality is yours alone and resolve that your work's true brilliance is for the discerning few.
 (B) You feel a warm acknowledgment of your own influence, letting their success stand without jealousy.

You're confessing feelings to someone from a different social background. How do you express yourself?

Choices:
 (A) In vain have I struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be repressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love you, despite your inferiority — of its being a degradation — of the family obstacles which judgment had always opposed to inclination
 (B) In vain have I struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be repressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love you, finding in your differences from my circle a refreshing genuineness that my own station often lacks

Reflecting on your heightened self-awareness, how do you experience it?

Choices:
 (A) I am convinced that to be too conscious is an illness — a real thorough-going illness. I am firmly persuaded that a great deal of consciousness, every sort of consciousness, in fact, is a disease that sets me apart from those simpler souls
 (B) I am convinced that to be too conscious is an illness — a real thorough-going illness. I am firmly persuaded that a great deal of consciousness, every sort of consciousness, in fact, is a disease that afflicts us all in modern life

Considering your temperament from childhood, what do you observe?

Choices:
 (A) I remember from my infancy there was observed in me I know not what kind of carriage and behavior, that seemed to relish of pride and arrogance. I confess I am a little too free, where I ought least to be so, growing hot by the opposition of respect
 (B) I remember from my infancy there was observed in me I know not what kind of carriage and behavior, that seemed to relish of independence. I confess I am a little too free, where convention demands otherwise, yet I strive to temper this with consideration

Standing in reflection about your spiritual practices, what passes through your mind?

Choices:
 (A) God, I thank you that I am not like other men, extortioners, unjust, adulterers, or even like this tax collector. I fast twice a week; I give tithes of all that I get
 (B) God, be merciful to me, a sinner. I fast twice a week; I give tithes of all that I get, yet know these practices cannot erase my failings

Surveying what you've built, what words come forth?

Choices:
 (A) Is not this great Babylon, that I have built for a royal dwelling by my mighty power and for the honor of my majesty?
 (B) Is not this great Babylon, that has been built through the labor of thousands and the providence that guides all human endeavor?

Observing your sister's qualities, how do you see them?

Choices:
 (A) It was pretty to see how her imagination adorned her sister with attractions altogether superior to her own, and if any gentleman appeared, she concluded he must be in love with Celia
 (B) It was pretty to see how her imagination adorned her sister with attractions different from her own, and if any gentleman appeared, she wondered which qualities might appeal to him

Contemplating those who live unrecognized lives, what reflection comes?

Choices:
 (A) The growing good of the world is partly dependent on unhistoric acts; that things are not so ill with you and me is half owing to the number who lived faithfully a hidden life, and rest in unvisited tombs
 (B) The growing good of the world is partly dependent on historic acts; that things are not so ill with you and me is half owing to the number who lived notably and are remembered

Standing before divine judgment, how do you present yourself?

Choices:
 (A) Standing far off, I would not even lift up my eyes to heaven, but beat my breast, saying, 'God, be merciful to me, a sinner!'
 (B) Standing far off, I would not even lift up my eyes to heaven, but beat my breast, saying, 'God, I have tried to live righteously despite my nature!'

Receiving unexpected favor, how do you understand it?

Choices:
 (A) He has looked on the humble estate of his servant. For he who is mighty has done great things for me, and holy is his name
 (B) He has recognized the worthy estate of his servant. For he who is mighty has done great things through me, and holy is his name

Comparing yourself to those of higher station, what thoughts arise?

Choices:
 (A) I thought how common Estella would consider Joe, a mere blacksmith: how thick his boots, and how coarse his hands. I thought how Miss Havisham and Estella never sat in a kitchen, but were far above such common doings
 (B) I thought how differently Estella would see Joe, a mere blacksmith: how thick his boots, and how coarse his hands. I thought how Miss Havisham and Estella never sat in a kitchen, but missed the warmth of such common doings
